Situation1: They greet a few customers politely while scanning items at a quiet store.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: An official explains that, because of a registration mismatch, the voter must complete a provisional ballot form before the station closes in ten minutes.
Story:
I was behind the register, scanning groceries and chatting with the few customers who trickled in. It was a slow afternoon, and I made sure to smile, ask about their day, and double-check every item. My manager always said that friendly service kept people coming back, and I took pride in making each person feel welcome. But my mind kept drifting to the election. I had just enough time to finish my shift and rush to the polling station before it closed.

When I arrived, breathless, an official frowned at my ID. “There’s a registration mismatch,” she said. “You’ll need to fill out a provisional ballot form. But you have to finish before we close in ten minutes.” I glanced at the long form and the clock. I remembered the training: follow every instruction exactly, no shortcuts, or my vote might not count.

My phone buzzed—my manager, asking if I could come back for a last-minute customer. I felt torn. As a cashier, I was supposed to be helpful and available. As a voter, I was supposed to follow every rule, no matter how rushed I felt. My hands shook as I stared at the form, caught between two worlds, unsure which expectation to meet.
